awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research in Economics: Evolutionary Preference Revelation Dynamics under School Choice Mechanisms
awd_abstract_narration:
Children in the United States are traditionally assigned to public schools based on where they live. However, a growing number of public school districts now allow parents to indicate which schools they want their children to attend. Since each school can support only a limited number of students, it is often impossible to give every student her top choice of schools. To resolve such shortages, policy makers employ student assignment mechanisms that assign each student to a school based on the reported preferences over schools and the legally determined student priorities at each school. In this study, we conduct laboratory experiments to investigate dynamic behavior under continuous-time variants of three widely employed school choice mechanisms. In these continuous-time mechanisms, participants adjust their preference reports asynchronously and receive instantaneous feedback regarding their assigned school. By providing considerable opportunity for learning and adjustment, these continuous-time mechanisms can promote rational behavior and achieve higher allocative efficiency. Accordingly, this study can help policy makers to select the best possible school choice mechanism for their district and improve educational outcomes for children who attend public schools.

Under manipulable mechanisms, such as the widely employed Boston mechanism, participants frequently have an incentive to strategically misreport their preferences. To encourage truthful preference reports, mechanism designers often employ strategy-proof mechanisms under which participants never have an incentive to misreport preferences, so truthful preference reporting is a weakly dominant strategy. In contrast to these theoretical predictions, previous experimental studies find that even strategy-proof mechanisms frequently fail to induce truthful preference revelation. Unlike previous studies, we consider assignment mechanisms under which participants adjust their preference reports asynchronously and receive instantaneous feedback regarding their assigned school. In particular, we consider continuous-time variations of three widely employed school choice mechanisms: the deferred acceptance mechanism, the top trading cycles mechanism, and the Boston mechanism. Since these continuous-time mechanisms provide considerable opportunity for learning and adjustment, they may promote rational preference revelation behavior, leading to more stable and more efficient outcomes under strategy proof mechanisms.

por.por_cntn:
This study examined and tested the theoretical predictions from adaptive models on three widely used school-choice mechanisms: the deferred acceptance mechanism, the top trading cycles mechanism, and the Boston mechanism. A school choice mechanism works as follows: individuals provide rankings of their preferred schools, schools provide rankings of their preferred students and the mechanism algorithmically assigns students to schools. Mechanisms are designed to achieve certain objectives. At equilibrium, the predicted outcome of standard game theory, the deferred acceptance and Boston mechanism are designed to eliminate "justified envy" and the top trading cycle is designed to maximize efficiency. In field applications, it is difficult to verify if these outcomes are achieved. After all, one can only infer individuals’ preferences from the rankings they provide to the mechanism, and individual rankings may differ from their true preferences for either strategic or irrational reasons. Those true preferences are essential to calculate the extent of justified envy or efficiency. Lab-based experiments provide a solution. We can generate specific preferences for subjects and examine whether these outcomes are achieved. 

Previous experiments find that student assignment mechanisms frequently fail achieve equilibrium outcomes. These departures may result because participants are not fully rational. We propose a possible improvement: the typical mechanism has participants make their choices up until a deadline and then reveals results at that deadline. We alternatively suggest revealing results during the entire reporting period, that is, revealing the outcome of what would happen had the deadline just occurred. Theories of adaptive models suggest that this type of assignment feedback may improve the number of equilibrium outcomes. To test this prediction and depart from conventional school choice design, we also provide participants with assignment feedback throughout the reporting period.

In all three mechanisms, subjects achieved equilibrium assignments significantly more often with assignment feedback throughout the reporting period than without. Subjects in the top trading cycles mechanism were significantly more likely to receive their most preferred school under continuous assignment feedback, a sign of greater efficiency. Subjects in the deferred acceptance mechanism and the Boston mechanism were significantly less likely to exhibit justified envy under continuous assignment feedback. Consistent with theoretical predictions, these experimental results suggest that providing additional feedback throughout the preference reporting period can help promote rational preference revelation behavior by giving participants more opportunity for learning and adjustment. The results of this study point towards new ways of providing feedback in school choice mechanisms to more effectively achieve policy goals.
